Yeah, so, as for federal taxation, federal taxes are not a funding mechanism for the federal government. Every time the federal government spends, it creates new dollars to fund that spending. That is how dollars are created and injected into the private sector. Federal taxes are how dollars are extracted from the private sector and destroyed. Federal taxes are not recycled. In fact, if you pay your taxes in cash, they literally shred it. In the olden days, back when all taxes were paid in cash, they burned it. This belief that taxes are recycled is a neoliberal bluff akin to believing that banks are financial intermediaries that take deposits and then lend those out. This is a strange faith in what was learned from George Bailey in It's a Wonderful Life. The financial intermediary theory of banking, like the fractional reserve theory of banking are complete bunk. There is no empirical evidence to support either of these theories. The only theory of banking that is empirically proven is the credit creation theory of banking. Imagine for a moment that the federal government asks you to pay a tax in dollars before it, the sole creator of the dollar, has spent it into existence. Is it possible? No. The federal government has to create that dollar before it can tax that dollar. And no, the federal government never borrows dollars to fund spending. Securities are a monetary tool used to control the overnight interest rate and a timed payout savings account. It is also not a funding mechanism. As for state taxes, yes, the state absolutely needs revenue before it can spend that revenue as it is not a currency creator. It's like comparing apples to a soccer ball.

Just throwing this out there: demand is impossible to quantify. It doesnt exist.

1) theres no such thing as rational choice. A supermarket has so many goods that its impossible to rationally consider what goes into your cart because it can hold more possible combinations of goods than there are particles in the universe.

So there's that.

Then 2) its impossible to know what people 'would' want. We only know what they end up buying. In fact, the concept of 'what a person "would" want' is absolutely unintelligible. In our lives we balance so many different trade off's... and our behaviour radically changes when money is short or plentiful... and the complicated circumstances in everyones lives are so complex that measuring this supposed quantity called "demand" becomes a non sequitur.

Its impossible to say how many toilet paper rolls someone "would" want... because if they farted sideways earlier in the day it could radically change their buying habits later. Its like chaos theory.

Then if this is the case, we are forced to face the fact that equilibrium doesnt exist. Equilibrium cant exist if half of the equation is undefined....

So now we see that economics isn't so much "true" as it is just a set of heuristics we can use to analyze the massively complicated and chaotic market.

Its important to keep this in mind, or we may be tempted to confuse heuristic models for actual laws or "facts" rather than just usefull sinplifications that arent real.

Then we crank out "economists" who believe these nebulous and logically impossible concepts such as equilibrium and demand, etc. Are real and wonder why we keep getting knocked on our asses when market disruptions happen.

We are constricting a limitlessly complicated and incomprehensibly interconnected economy into illogically simple models.

I know that phd's in economics know fantastically conplicated things that i couldnt even hope to comprehend.. like econometrics... stuff that is more mathematics and programming than what people typically think of as economics.

And that stuff is probably super useful.

But when it comes to labour economics... macro econ with supply and demand curves... market movements on a large scale... i think we need to recognise that the classical economics approach is just too rigid and hypothetical to possibly apply to the real world.

What you're missing is that this is just a model. Sure there's economies of scale but you're not taking into account marginal benefits. As you get closer to full capacity and over your workers might get in each other way. Eventually it would be better to increase capacity by getting new land and more workers, but they might have a better marginal benefit else where in society.
